conclusion: The image shows four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on a flat surface.
The light source is initially positioned above and slightly behind the objects, casting shadows forward.
Shadow A is cast by the vase.
Shadow B is cast by the picture frame.
Shadow C is cast by the bottle.
Shadow D is cast by the toilet paper roll.
The light source moves forward, above the objects.
All shadows will move closer to their respective objects because the light source is moving forward.
As the light source moves closer to the objects, the angle of incidence becomes more perpendicular, which generally results in a slight reduction in shadow size.
Since the light source is moving forward and not directly closer to the objects, the change in size may not be significant unless the light is very close to the objects initially.
The key step illustration confirms the position and direction of the shadows. As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift towards the objects, becoming shorter.
Shadows A, B, C, and D move closer to their respective objects.
Shadows will likely become slightly smaller, but the change may not be very noticeable depending on the initial distance of the light source.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects and may become slightly smaller.
